body:
Cult or gentlemanly fraternity? I was recently sought out by a mutual friend and invited to a meeting, they seemed quite friendly and told me since membership has been in decline over the years they are accepting more people from all different walks of life. You can literally go online and find their websites where they welcome inquiries.

Pending a background check I was told I would be welcome to a lodge meeting sometime soon (no in person meetings due to Covid-19 currently).

I'm genuinely interested, I'm also intrigued with the secrecy and Freemason customs (handshakes etc) so joining might give me an excuse to collect information for a book someday, while in the meantime giving me new friends and fellows to discuss anything with.

What do you think +AskRuqqus?

Pending a background check I was told I would be welcome to a lodge meeting sometime soon (no in person meetings due to Covid-19 currently).

I'm genuinely interested, I'm also intrigued with the secrecy and Freemason customs (handshakes etc) so joining might give me an excuse to collect information for a book someday, while in the meantime giving me new friends and fellows to discuss anything with.

What do you think +AskRuqqus?

title: What's your opinion on Freemasonry?

body:
I believe Count Dankula did a video on a secret society involving pug worship you might want to check out, yeah it's not necessarily anything bad, it looks like it's like a male fraternity group that likes to shroud itself in 'mystery' for the sake of appearances and make themselves seem exclusive. It is worth pointing out though groups like that often have things like hazing rituals etc. and they'll probably get you involved in some weird shit, just important to make sure you're okay with that if you do end up joining them from what I've heard about them. 

One of the weirdest things I've ever heard about groups like this is something which involved David Cameron where he apparently stuck his penis in a pigs head at a party in front of everyone. The people who run these groups are fucking weird lol it does get you contacts and so on but I would of course argue there's better ways to make friends than joining a secret society that does hazing rituals on you. They will try to get you to do weird shit in order to get in good with them and it's not surprise that their membership has likely dropped like a rock because of crap like that.

One of the weirdest things I've ever heard about groups like this is something which involved David Cameron where he apparently stuck his penis in a pigs head at a party in front of everyone. post.title: What's your opinion on Freemasonry?

body:
Funny you mention the Count Dankula video, I just watched it today! I found it funny.

I am honestly interested in the connections aspect and forming friendships, we will see how I go as they need to all vote whether I am to be accepted and if someone at all declines I believe it's a no.

I am assuming they have fewer and fewer numbers so they might be more eager to admit me vs a larger city lodge.

Though if I am declined it's no fuss, I enjoy my freedom from expected commitments but Freemasonry is something I'm willing to commit my time to.

post.title: What's your opinion on Freemasonry?

body:
It's an adult social club for men. My great grandparents were Freemason/Order of the Eastern Star and as far as I can tell it was a way for them to socialize and gain a community after immigrating and having children. 

I think the secrecy is hyped up for fun for members and to feel a little more important.
body_html:
It's an adult social club for men. My great grandparents were Freemason/Order of the Eastern Star and as far as I can tell it was a way for them to socialize and gain a community after immigrating and having children.

I think the secrecy is hyped up for fun for members and to feel a little more important.

post.title: What's your opinion on Freemasonry?

author.bio: Unironic Anarcho-Monarchist. I also collect stamps.

body:
It seems clear that Freemasonry has a strong spiritual dimention to it, with rituals based on the myth of Hiram the Master Builder. Fatherhood of God and Brotherhood of Man, cultivating your virtues, type of stuff. However, I know many people have critised the Freemasons for not focusing enough on the spiritual and magickal practice and just being a "gentleman's club", and those people usually end up joining magickal orders like the Rectified Scottish Rite, Martinism, Order of the Golden Dawn etc.

I think it is also worth mentioning the Odd Fellows, which is often conceived of as "Freemasonry-Lite" but is its own ritual system, also based on Biblical myths. Fraternal orders and magickal orders are truly a rabbit hole worth exploring. 

If collecting info for a book, keep in mind that breaking a Masonic oath is a very serious offence. Like 90% of all Freemasonry is available on the internet anyways, it's not really that secret. You might not literally be killed for breaking an oath (as has happened in ages past), but it will ostracise you from the community, which may or may not have real-world consequences, depending on how much power the Freemasons actually have. Cue tinfoil hat. 

Also keep in mind that the Catholic Church has ruled many times over that a Catholic cannot become a Freemason and remain in good standing with the Church, and many Christian denominations have forbidden members from becoming Freemasons, if you care about that kind of thing. It is not so clear-cut however, as some denominations, most notably State Lutheranism in Scandinavia, have a very good relationship with the Freemasons in those countries.
body_html:
It seems clear that Freemasonry has a strong spiritual dimention to it, with rituals based on the myth of Hiram the Master Builder. Fatherhood of God and Brotherhood of Man, cultivating your virtues, type of stuff. However, I know many people have critised the Freemasons for not focusing enough on the spiritual and magickal practice and just being a "gentleman's club", and those people usually end up joining magickal orders like the Rectified Scottish Rite, Martinism, Order of the Golden Dawn etc.

I think it is also worth mentioning the Odd Fellows, which is often conceived of as "Freemasonry-Lite" but is its own ritual system, also based on Biblical myths. Fraternal orders and magickal orders are truly a rabbit hole worth exploring.

If collecting info for a book, keep in mind that breaking a Masonic oath is a very serious offence. Like 90% of all Freemasonry is available on the internet anyways, it's not really that secret. You might not literally be killed for breaking an oath (as has happened in ages past), but it will ostracise you from the community, which may or may not have real-world consequences, depending on how much power the Freemasons actually have. Cue tinfoil hat.

Also keep in mind that the Catholic Church has ruled many times over that a Catholic cannot become a Freemason and remain in good standing with the Church, and many Christian denominations have forbidden members from becoming Freemasons, if you care about that kind of thing. It is not so clear-cut however, as some denominations, most notably State Lutheranism in Scandinavia, have a very good relationship with the Freemasons in those countries.

post.body:
Cult or gentlemanly fraternity? I was recently sought out by a mutual friend and invited to a meeting, they seemed quite friendly and told me since membership has been in decline over the years they are accepting more people from all different walks of life. You can literally go online and find their websites where they welcome inquiries.

Pending a background check I was told I would be welcome to a lodge meeting sometime soon (no in person meetings due to Covid-19 currently).

I'm genuinely interested, I'm also intrigued with the secrecy and Freemason customs (handshakes etc) so joining might give me an excuse to collect information for a book someday, while in the meantime giving me new friends and fellows to discuss anything with.

What do you think +AskRuqqus?
post.body_html:

What do you think +AskRuqqus?
post.title: What's your opinion on Freemasonry?

body: It's a LARP. Elks lodge with white gloves and incense.

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
From what I understand it's a self improvement society, but no one with bad character is allowed, which kinda defeats the purpose. To me it sounds like a club where people go to feel like they're superior to everyone else.

I doubt they're connected to the elites, at least not these days, but in places with a high population of freemasons it's true that having that ring on your finger has its advantages.
body_html:
From what I understand it's a self improvement society, but no one with bad character is allowed, which kinda defeats the purpose. To me it sounds like a club where people go to feel like they're superior to everyone else.

I doubt they're connected to the elites, at least not these days, but in places with a high population of freemasons it's true that having that ring on your finger has its advantages.

post.title: What's your opinion on Freemasonry?

body: It's like the Catholic church.  An organization where funds go up the chain and 99% of the members have absolutely NO CLUE what happens to their money. The 1% are the true members, going back 100s of years.  No matter how long you're in it, you will never know what that 1% does and you will never become one of them.
body_html: It's like the Catholic church. An organization where funds go up the chain and 99% of the members have absolutely NO CLUE what happens to their money. The 1% are the true members, going back 100s of years. No matter how long you're in it, you will never know what that 1% does and you will never become one of them.

body: It might be 'fine' at the beginning but you'd definitely find some satanic worship going on if you actually managed to get to the top levels of the organization.
